glosses: Derives names of animals, mainly but not exclusively birds, which denote their diet or their tendency to prey on a certain type of animal.

examples.text: balık (“fish”) + -çıl → balıkçıl (“heron”, literally “that which feeds on fish”)
arı (“bee”) + -cıl → arıcıl (“bee-eater”, literally “that which feeds on bees”)

glosses: Derives names of plants or animals, which denote their tendency or preference to habitate a certain type of environment or location.

examples.text: batak (“bog, marsh”) + -çıl → batakçıl (“that which lives, likes to live in swamps, swampy areas”)
kurak (“dry, arid”) + -çıl → kurakçıl (“that which lives, likes to live in a dry, arid environment”)
dağ (“mountain”) + -cıl → dağcıl (“that which lives, likes to live on mountains, in mountainous areas”)

glosses: Derives adjectives from nouns, which denote a tendency, fondness, habit, affection or dependency towards an action or behaviour.
Adds the meaning of tendency, willingness or closeness.

examples.text: ön (“front, anterior”) + -cül → öncül (“that which leads, leading”)
art (“back, rear”) + -çıl → artçıl (“that which comes from behind, latter”)

glosses: Adds the meaning of similarity, likeness.
